status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

worklogs.comment:
nealrichardson commented on pull request #5173: ARROW-5176: [Python] Automate formatting of python files
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5173
 
 
   Here's the diff of running `black` on the python directory. As I said on https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-5176, I'd also be in favor of a precommit hook to run black on every commit, but I'll leave that up to those who have more of a stake in this.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------

To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the

users@infra.apache.org

wesm commented on issue #5173: ARROW-5176: [Python] Automate formatting of python files
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5173#issuecomment-524128204
 
 
   Hm some of black's formatting choices are ... special. It seems that aligning code at parenthesis offsets is not used, and we have a lot of code like that. I'll let other Python folks opine about how to proceed. 
   
   If we're going to use black we need to add it to our lint CI step so we don't have spurious diffs
   
   Can black format Cython code?
 
----------------------------------------------------------------

jorisvandenbossche commented on issue #5173: ARROW-5176: [Python] Automate formatting of python files
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5173#issuecomment-524189641
 
 
   I also don't like all choices that black makes, but my experience with pandas (where we started using it recently), is that it is so much nicer to not have to worry about formatting.
   
   So +1 on using black.
   
   If doing so, we should indeed add a check in CI and a precommit hook

 Review comment:
   Yes, I agree this is horrible. But in this case it could be rather easily "solved" by defining those 3 types on itself just before creating the schema. 
   
   Although it would still not be beautiful. The most nested one from above would become:
   
   ```
   df test():
       ...
       map_type = pa.list_(
           pa.struct(
               [
                   ("key", pa.string()),
                   ("value", pa.struct([("int1", pa.int32()), ("string1", pa.string())])),
               ]
           )
       )
       expected_schema = ...
   ```

xhochy commented on issue #5173: ARROW-5176: [Python] Automate formatting of python files
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5173#issuecomment-524310313
 
 
   I'm also +1 on black as it removes the cognitive load for working correctly formatting code and the time spent in discussion about how to format it.
   
   Ugly formatted code will exists as with any other fixed code formatting guideline but my experience has been that many of those snippets are solved by making the code itself simpler and more readable. The remaining small percentage that looks ugly is a happy tradeoff for the code formatting automation for me.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------

issuetype.description: A new feature of the product, which has yet to be developed.
issuetype.name: New Feature

fields.description: [Black](https://github.com/ambv/black) is a tool for automatically formatting python code in ways which flake8 and our other linters approve of. Adding it to the project will allow more reliably formatted python code and fill a similar role to {{clang-format}} for c++ and {{cmake-format}} for cmake

comments.body: I have used black in many other projects and am very happy with it. One of the major benefits is that it is not configurable and thus also saves us from long discussions about styling.

+1 for this, and I'll go further and propose a pre-commit hook to run `black` so that developers don't have to waste energy thinking about linting. At a minimum we should add a pre-commit hook that runs flake8 (per the [dev instructions|https://github.com/apache/arrow/blob/master/docs/source/developers/python.rst#coding-style]). I got a Travis failure for linting, and IMO that should never happen.
There hasn't been all that much Python churn lately. Seems like it might be a good "lull" to begin using Black. thoughts?
I just made a PR with the blackened codebase, for consideration.
This isn't urgent to address for 0.15.0

Shall we "just do it" ? I just needed to manually format a full file where I did a search/replace which caused a lot of "line too long" flake8 errors, for which it would have been nice to use an automatic formatter, like black.
Would be very happy with that!
{{archery lint --python --fix}} will now automatically format Python code
